INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
T03-13A = TREATMENT EARLY IN LIFE WITH THE LECTIN CONA DECELERATES SPREADING DEPRESSION IN WELL-NOURISHED AND EARLY-MALNOURISHED ADULT RATS
G. S. Ferreira Soares, L. Cabral Cavalcanti, R.C. A. Guedes
Universidade Federal de Pernambuco, Recife, Brazil

Early nutritional insults have important effects on neural and glial electrophysiological activity because nutrients regulate brain development during early postnatal life, when neural and glial cells present higher degree of plasticity. Herein we characterized in adult rats the electrophysiological changes caused by the systemic treatment early in life with the lectin ConA by recording the electrophysiological phenomenon of cortical spreading depression (CSD). Additionally, we evaluated the impact of early nutritional deficiency on the CSD effects of ConA. 
Methods: Two nutritionally distinct groups of male newborn rats ? well-nourished (W; n = 26) and malnourished (M; n = 33) were treated from the 5th to the 24th day of postnatal life with daily intraperitoneal injections of saline (Sal) or ConA (Sigma-Aldrich) at doses of 1 mg/kg (group W-L1 and M-L1) or 10 mg/kg (Groups W-L10 and M-L10). Two groups of ?naive? (non-injected) pups were used as additional controls. When the pups reached adult age (90?120 days), under ip anesthesia (1 g/kg urethane140 mg/kg chloralose) they were submitted to the CSD recording (ECoG and slow potential change) in two points of the parietal cortical surface. CSD was triggered every 20 minutes by applying 2% KCl for 1 min at a point in the frontal cortex. This study was approved by the ethics committee of our University, Case No.:23076.031272/2010-53.
Results: Compared to W-Sal controls (mean ± sd velocity in mm/min = 3.41 ± 0.10), M-Sal rats presented significantly higher velocities (4.26 ± 0.16; p < 0.05). In both nutritional conditions L1 and L10 treated groups presented significantly lower CSD velocities (3.12 ± 0.14 and 2.82 ± 0.18 for the W-L1 and W-L10, respectively, and 3.74

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
A vitamina C, ou ácido ascórbico (AA) é um nutriente encontrado em grande concentração no cérebro, sendo amplamente conhecido por sua ação antioxidante. Seu efeito sobre o sistema nervoso central parece ser dependente da dose empregada, podendo, sob certas condições, facilitar a oxidação ao invés de agir como antioxidante. Em estudo anterior (Neurosci. Lett. 496:191, 2011), o tratamento com 60 mg/kg/dia durante 3 semanas facilitou a propagação da depressão alastrante cortical (DAC); entretanto, não se conhecia o efeito de doses menores ou maiores.
Objetivo: Avaliar, em ratos albinos, os efeitos eletrofisiológicos da administração crônica de crescentes doses de vitamina C (30, 60 e 120 mg/kg/dia) sobre o sistema nervoso em desenvolvimento, através do fenômeno da DAC.
Métodos: Ratos Wistar (n=53) foram distribuídos em 5 grupos experimentais, que receberam diariamente, do 7º ao 28º dia de vida, os seguintes tratamentos por gavagem: solução salina (n= 9) ou vitamina C, em diferentes doses (30, 60 e 120 mg/kg/dia; n= 15, 6 e 12, respectivamente). Um quinto grupo não recebeu tratamento por gavagem, sendo denominado como naïve (ingênuo; n=11). Entre 30 e 40 dias de idade, os animais foram anestesiados e submetidos ao registro eletrofisiológico da DAC, em 2 pontos da superfície cortical direita, por 4 horas. A DAC foi deflagrada a cada 20 minutos por estimulação de um ponto cortical com KCl a 2%. Nos diferentes grupos, foram comparadas as velocidades de propagação da DAC, calculadas com base no tempo gasto pelo fenômeno para percorrer a distância entre os pontos de registro. Os dados foram analisados estatisticamente com a ANOVA, seguida de teste ?post hoc? (Holm-Sidak), quando indicado. Foram consideradas significantes as diferenças em que p≤0,05.
Resultados: O grupo tratado com a dose baixa de vitamina C (30 mg/kg/dia) apresentou velocidades de propagação da DAC significativamente menores (2,97±0,18 mm/min) que os grupos ingênuo e salina (respectivamente, 3,87 ±

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Imunorreatividade astrocitária no cortex cerebral de ratos em desenvolvimento submetidos ao exercício físico após tratamento sistêmico com glutamato monossódico.

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DOS-ANAIS-OU-PROCEEDINGS: XXXVIII Reunião Anual da SBNeC - Sociedade Brasileira de Neurociências e Comportamento - Programa - SBNEC 2014 - 10-13 de setembro de 2014, Búzios-RJ.

AUTORES.NOME-COMPLETO-DO-AUTOR: Belmira Lara da Silveira Andrade da Costa

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Glutamato monossódico (MSG), um aminoácido neuroexcitatório utilizado como reforçador do sabor dos alimentos (?agente flavorizante?). Quando utilizado em altas doses, pode ser prejudicial ao sistema nervoso central, às células neuronais e gliais, desencadeando uma reação astrocitária. Isto é mais severo durante o desenvolvimento cerebral. Em ratos, o MSG no período neonatal pode induzir neurotoxicidade, afetando a organização morfológica e eletrofisiológica do encéfalo (Life Sci. 93:388, 2013). Por outo lado, o exercício físico induz efeitos positivos no sistema nervoso de mamíferos. Nosso objetivo com este estudo, foi investigar, em ratos tratados com MSG e/ou exercício físico em esteira, a reação astrocitária expressa pela imuno-marcação com anticorpos anti GFAP no córtex motor. Ratos Wistar ( n=4-5 por cada grupo), receberam MSG (2 ou 4g/kg, respectivamente; grupos MSG-2 e MSG-4), ou solução salina , ou nenhum tratamento (grupo ingênuo) a cada dois dias, nos primeiros 14 dias de vida pós-natal. Após o desmame, os três grupos foram subdivididos em exercitados (esteira motorizada, 3 semanas, 5 dias/semana, durante 30 minutos, ou sedentários. Dois dias após o final do exercício, os cérebros foram perfundidos e crioprotegidos. Cortes de 40 micrômetros de espessura foram processados para imuno-marcação de células astrocitárias (com anticorpo anti-GFAP). Comparado ao grupo salina, os animais tratados com MSG 2g-4g/kg apresentaram um aumento de imunorreatividade com diferença significativa entre eles, mostrando um aumento do gurpo 4g/kg comparado com o grupo de 2 g/kg, sendo o mesmo resultado para os grupos sedentários e exercitados. Nos grupos tratados com MSG, o exercício físico exerceu influência aumentando a porcentagem de área marcada; efeito oposto ocorreu em relação ao grupo salina. Os dados sugerem cautela na utilização de MSG como reforçador do sabor dos alimentos, principalmente no organismo em desenvolvimento (crianças) e indicam que o exercício físico pode i
INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES: Glutamato monossódico (MSG), um aminoácido neuroexcitatório utilizado como reforçador do sabor dos alimentos (?agente flavorizante?). Quando utilizado em altas doses, pode ser prejudicial ao sistema nervoso central, às células neuronais e gliais, desencadeando uma reação astrocitária. Isto é mais severo durante o desenvolvimento cerebral. Em ratos, o MSG no período neonatal pode induzir neurotoxicidade, afetando a organização morfológica e eletrofisiológica do encéfalo (Life Sci. 93:388, 2013). Por outo lado, o exercício físico induz efeitos positivos no sistema nervoso de mamíferos. Nosso objetivo com este estudo, foi investigar, em ratos tratados com MSG e/ou exercício físico em esteira, a reação astrocitária expressa pela imuno-marcação com anticorpos anti GFAP no córtex motor. Ratos Wistar ( n=4-5 por cada grupo), receberam MSG (2 ou 4g/kg, respectivamente; grupos MSG-2 e MSG-4), ou solução salina , ou nenhum tratamento (grupo ingênuo) a cada dois dias, nos primeiros 14 dias de vida pós-natal. Após o desmame, os três grupos foram subdivididos em exercitados (esteira motorizada, 3 semanas, 5 dias/semana, durante 30 minutos, ou sedentários. Dois dias após o final do exercício, os cérebros foram perfundidos e crioprotegidos. Cortes de 40 micrômetros de espessura foram processados para imuno-marcação de células astrocitárias (com anticorpo anti-GFAP). Comparado ao grupo salina, os animais tratados com MSG 2g-4g/kg apresentaram um aumento de imunorreatividade com diferença significativa entre eles, mostrando um aumento do gurpo 4g/kg comparado com o grupo de 2 g/kg, sendo o mesmo resultado para os grupos sedentários e exercitados. Nos grupos tratados com MSG, o exercício físico exerceu influência aumentando a porcentagem de área marcada; efeito oposto ocorreu em relação ao grupo salina. Os dados sugerem cautela na utilização de MSG como reforçador do sabor dos alimentos, principalmente no organismo em desenvolvimento (crianças) e indicam que o exercício físico pode i

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO-INGLES: feito da cafeína, administrada em diferentes fases do desenvolvimento, sobre a atenção em ratos.

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DOS-ANAIS-OU-PROCEEDINGS: XXXVIII Reunião Anual da SBNeC - Sociedade Brasileira de Neurociências e Comportamento - Programa - SBNEC 2014 - 10-13 de setembro de 2014, Búzios-RJ.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
INTRODUÇÃO: A cafeína (CAF) tem ação estimulante sobre o Sistema Nervoso Central e pode alterar certos comportamentos, como o de atenção. A Inibição Latente (LI) é um modelo experimental para o estudo da atenção. Certos estimulantes eliminam a LI, ou seja, dificultam a atenção. No rato, o período do aleitamento (do nascimento até o 21º dia de vida) é muito importante para o desenvolvimento morfo-fisiológico cerebral, e, neste período, o cérebro é muito vulnerável à ação de drogas.
OBJETIVOS: analisar, em ratos adultos, o efeito da administração de CAF em diferentes fases do desenvolvimento, sobre a atenção, através do modelo da LI.
MÉTODO E RESULTADOS: Ratos Wistar machos foram tratados durante todo o aleitamento (experimento 1; 30 mg/kg/d) ou na vida adulta (experimento 2; 30 mg/kg, 30 min antes da LI) com CAF, s.c., ou salina (n=20 no expto.1 e n=16 no expto.2, em cada tratamento). Em ambos os experimentos a LI foi avaliada aos 75-85 dias de vida. Sob restrição de água, os ratos, foram submetidos às seguintes fases do procedimento de LI: a) Pré-exposição (3 dias): à solução de sacarose a 5% (grupo PE) ou água (grupo NPE); b) Condicionamento (4º dia) pareamento solução de sacarose ? injeção de LiCl (50 mg/kg, ip); c) Teste (5º dia): efeito do LiCl sobre o consumo de solução de sacarose. A ANOVA 2X2 revelou, no Experimento 1 (tratamento no aleitamento), efeito significativo da exposição à sacarose (PE e NPE - F(1,36)=6,232, p<0,05), indicando efeito da LI (PE>NPE), tanto no grupo SAL quanto no CAF (razões de supressão média±erro padrão: PE=0,53±0,11 e 0,71±0,09, e NPE=0,32±0,11 e 0,41±0,10). No Experimento 2 (tratamento na vida adulta), houve efeito significativo da exposição à sacarose (PE e NPE - F(1,28)=5,737, p<0,05), e da interação exposição X droga (F(1,28)=8,336, p<0,01). Os dados revelaram efeito LI apenas nos animais tratados com SAL (razões de supressão: PE=0,75±0,05 e NPE=0,28±0,06). A LI foi abolida nos animais tratados com CAF, durante as fases do pro

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Efeito de uma dieta hipoprotéica, administrada durante o aleitamento, sobre a atenção, em ratos jovens.
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO-INGLES: Efeito de uma dieta hipoprotéica, administrada durante o aleitamento, sobre a atenção, em ratos jovens.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
INTRODUÇÂO: A carência de proteína na dieta, durante a gestação, pode interferir na formação do embrião, e, no período da lactação, influi no desenvolvimento do organismo, devido à diminuição da produção de leite pela mãe. Isso pode comprometer funções neuropsíquicas, como a atenção. A Inibição Latente (LI) é um modelo experimental para o estudo da atenção. A LI foi empregada neste trabalho, em ratos submetidos a dieta hipoprotéica.
OBJETIVO: analisar o efeito de uma dieta hipoprotéica, administrada durante o aleitamento, sobre a atenção, através do modelo da LI, em ratos jovens. 
MÉTODO E RESULTADOS: Ratos Wistar, recém-nascidos, foram amamentados por mães alimentadas com dieta normoproteica (dieta ?Labina?, de manutenção do biotério [MB], ou dieta contendo caseína [CASEÍ], uma proteína do leite), ambas com 23% de proteínas. Eles foram comparados a animais tratados com dieta hipoproteica (CASEÍ com 8% de proteínas). Após o desmame (25º Dia), todos receberam a dieta controle (MB). Aos 35-45 dias (ratos jovens, MB 121,7g; CASEÍ 23%, 122,5g e CASEÍ 8%, 99,4g de peso corporal), sob restrição de água, foram submetidos à LI, em procedimento durando 5 dias com 3 fases: a) Pré-exposição, do 1º. Ao 3º. dia, a um estímulo neutro (solução de sacarose a 5%; grupo PE) ou a água (grupo NPE); b) Condicionamento (4º dia), que consiste no pareamento da solução de sacarose com um estímulo aversivo (injeção de LiCl [25 mg/kg, ip]); c) Teste (5º dia): quando se avalia o efeito do LiCl sobre a resposta de consumo de solução de sacarose. Os animais foram subdivididos em 6 grupos: MB PE (n=8); MB NPE (n=8); CASEÍ 23% PE (n=10); CASEÍ 23% NPE (n=10); CASEÍ 8% PE (n=10) e CASEÍ 8% NPE (n=10). A ANOVA 2X3 revelou, efeito significativo de exposição (PE e NPE - F(1,50)=39,686, p<0,01), e do tipo de dieta (MB, CASEÍ 23% e CASEÍ 8% - F(2,50)= 10,740, p<0,01) e da interação exposição e dieta (F(2,50)=17,331, p<0,01). Os dados indicaram efeito da LI (PE>NPE) apenas nos grupos mantidos com MB e

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Caracterização da depressão alastrante cortical em ratas adultas previamente submetidas ao tratamento sistêmico com progesterona durante o desenvolvimento cerebral.
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO-INGLES: Caracterização da depressão alastrante cortical em ratas adultas previamente submetidas ao tratamento sistêmico com progesterona durante o desenvolvimento cerebral.

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: XXXVIII Reunião Anual da SBNeC- Soc. Brasileira de Neurociencias e Comportamento.
DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DOS-ANAIS-OU-PROCEEDINGS: XXXVIII Reunião Anual da SBNeC - Sociedade Brasileira de Neurociências e Comportamento - Programa - SBNEC 2014 - 10-13 de setembro de 2014, Búzios-RJ.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
INTRODUÇÃO: O sistema nervoso central dos mamíferos é um importante órgão alvo dos hormônios ovarianos desde o seu desenvolvimento à idade adulta. Eles atravessam livremente a barreira hematoencefálica e exercem efeitos profundos sobre a excitabilidade cerebral. Em estudo prévio (Intern.J.Dev.Neurosci. 30:405, 2012) demonstramos em ratas que a ovariectomia no início da vida reduz a propagação do fenômeno denominado Depressão Alastrante Cortical (DAC) na idade adulta. Um estudo in vitro em ratos adultos (Neurobiol. Dis. 25:27, 2007) sugere uma possível influência facilitadora, dose-dependente, da progesterona sobre a DAC.
OBJETIVOS: Neste estudo objetivou-se caracterizar eletrofisiologicamente, in vivo, alterações na capacidade cerebral de propagar DAC em ratas adultas tratadas com progesterona no início da vida, como índice dos efeitos da aplicação sistêmica de progesterona durante o desenvolvimento sobre a eletrofisiologia cerebral da rata adulta.
MÉTODOS: Um grupo de ratas Wistar recebeu por via intraperitoneal (dos 7 aos 21 dias de vida, em dias alternados) progesterona (50µg/kg; n=8) e foi comparado a grupos injetados com o veículo (azeite de oliva; grupo V; n=8) ou sem tratamento (?ingênuo?; grupo I; n=12). Aos 90-120 dias de idade, foram submetidas ao registro da DAC, em 2 pontos corticais por 4 h. Em todos os experimentos, os registros da DAC foram feitos sempre na fase de proestro. A análise estatística foi feita com ANOVA seguida do Teste de Holm-Sidak, com nível de significância P<0,05. Aprovado pelo Comitê de Ética. Processo nº 23076.046121/2011-81.
RESULTADOS: O grupo que recebeu progesterona apresentou velocidade média de propagação da DAC (3,91±0,26 mm/min) significantemente maior (P<0,05) do que as dos grupos V (3,38±0,09) e I (3,33±0,12). 
CONCLUSÃO: O tratamento sistêmico com progesterona durante o período do desenvolvimento cerebral está associado com a aceleração da DAC no cérebro adulto, indicando um efeito facilitador de longo prazo. Sugerim

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Potenciação da amplitude do eletrocorticograma associada à depressão alastrante em ratos submetidos ao exercício de natação.
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO-INGLES: Potenciação da amplitude do eletrocorticograma associada à depressão alastrante em ratos submetidos ao exercício de natação.

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: XXXVIII Reunião Anual da SBNeC- Soc. Brasileira de Neurociencias e Comportamento.
DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DOS-ANAIS-OU-PROCEEDINGS: XXXVIII Reunião Anual da SBNeC - Sociedade Brasileira de Neurociências e Comportamento - Programa - SBNEC 2014 - 10-13 de setembro de 2014, Búzios-RJ.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Introdução: Evidências científicas demonstram efeitos positivos do exercício físico sobre o cérebro, podendo melhorar a função cognitiva e influenciar a excitabilidade neuronal. A depressão alastrante cortical (DAC) e a potenciação de longa duração (LTP) são fenômenos neurais relacionados com a excitabilidade cerebral. Anteriormente, descrevemos em ratos, in vivo, uma potenciação da atividade elétrica cortical espontânea (ECoG) associada à DAC (Exp. Brain Res. 214: 463, 2011). Neste estudo, examinamos a influência do exercício sobre esse efeito.
Objetivos: Investigar o efeito da natação sobre a capacidade da DAC, em potenciar a atividade elétrica cerebral, em ratos, in vivo.
Métodos: Ratos Wistar machos foram submetidos, do 60º ao 75º dia de vida pós-natal, a sessões de natação, sem resistência adicional nas patas, entre 8:00 e 12:00h da manhã, em recipiente plástico (50 cm de diâmetro), com água mantida a 31±1ºC (grupo N, n=12). Após 3 dias de adaptação (nadando 2, 5 e 10 min respectivamente); descansam 2 dias e nadam nos 5 dias seguintes 15, 20, 25, 30 e 40 min/dia; mais 2 d de descanso e terminam com 40 min/dia por mais 5 d. Esse grupo foi comparado a um grupo sedentário (S; n=10), colocado no mesmo recipiente, com o nível da água muito baixo, possibilitando o apoio das patas no fundo do recipiente. Aos 90-120 dias de idade, eles foram submetidos ao registro (sistema digital de registro: Biopac MP 100,USA) da atividade elétrica cortical espontânea (ECoG), na região parietal direita, em dois pontos: anterior e posterior, durante 2h (Período Basal). Logo após, mantendo-se o mesmo ganho dos amplificadores, a DAC foi deflagrada, a cada 20-30min pela estimulação com KCl a 2%, e o ECoG registrado por mais 2h (Período DAC). Quatro amostras do ECoG (10 minutos cada), sendo 2 representativas do registro basal, e 2 do período DAC foram analisadas, off-line, com o auxílio de um algorítimo implementado no software MATLAB(TM), versão R2011b, que calcula as amplitudes média

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Suplementação crônica com taurina e alanina no início da vida reduz a propagação da depressão alastrante cortical em ratos nutridos e desnutridos.
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO-INGLES: Suplementação crônica com taurina e alanina no início da vida reduz a propagação da depressão alastrante cortical em ratos nutridos e desnutridos.

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: XXXVIII Reunião Anual da SBNeC- Soc. Brasileira de Neurociencias e Comportamento.
DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DOS-ANAIS-OU-PROCEEDINGS: XXXVIII Reunião Anual da SBNeC - Sociedade Brasileira de Neurociências e Comportamento - Programa - SBNEC 2014 - 10-13 de setembro de 2014, Búzios-RJ.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Introdução: A taurina (Tau) é abundante em várias áreas do SNC, sendo reconhecida como um importante aminoácido inibitório distribuído nesse tecido. Por sua vez, a alanina (Ala), um inibidor do transporte de taurina, tem sido sugerido como neurotransmissor inibitório, por sua ação nos receptores GABAérgicos e Glicinérgicos. Os efeitos eletrofisiológicos neurais da suplementação desses aminoácidos, durante o desenvolvimento do SNC tem sido ainda pouco estudados.
Objetivo: Investigamos, em ratos albinos, o efeito da suplementação crônica com taurina e alanina no início da vida, associada ou não a condições desfavoráveis de lactação, sobre o fenômeno da depressão alastrante cortical (DAC), cuja propagação é influenciada pela excitabilidade cerebral.
Métodos: Ratos Wistar (n=86) foram submetidos a duas condições distintas de lactação: 1) lactação normal (N9; 44 ratos) e 2) lactação desfavorável (N15; 42 ratos), caracterizadas por amamentação em ninhadas com 9 e 15 filhotes, respectivamente. Em cada condição de lactação, os filhotes foram tratados diariamente, do 7º ao 27º dia de vida, por gavagem, com: [1] água (Wa; n=11 e 10, para as condições N9 e N15); [2] Tau (300 mg/kg/dia; n=11 da condição N9 e 11 N15); [3] Ala (300 mg/kg/dia; n=11 N9 e 11 N15); [4] o quarto grupo não recebeu qualquer tratamento e foi denominado ?naïve? (Nv; n=11 N9 e 10 N15). Entre 30 e 35 dias de vida, sob anestesia, os animais foram submetidos ao registro eletrofisiológico da DAC, em 2 pontos da superfície cortical direita, por 4 horas. A DAC foi deflagrada a cada 20 minutos por estimulação de um ponto cortical com KCl a 2%. Foram comparadas as velocidades de propagação da DAC, calculadas com base no tempo gasto pelo fenômeno para percorrer a distância entre os 2 pontos de registro. Os dados foram analisados estatisticamente com a ANOVA, seguida de teste ?post hoc? (Holm-Sidak), quando indicado. 
Resultados: Em comparação aos grupos controle de mesma condição nutricional, os grupos tratados

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Efeitos eletrofisiológicos da aplicação tópica do glutamato monossódico no córtex cerebral de ratos adultos submetidos ao exercício físico.
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO-INGLES: Efeitos eletrofisiológicos da aplicação tópica do glutamato monossódico no córtex cerebral de ratos adultos submetidos ao exercício físico.

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DOS-ANAIS-OU-PROCEEDINGS: XXXVIII Reunião Anual da SBNeC - Sociedade Brasileira de Neurociências e Comportamento - Programa - SBNEC 2014 - 10-13 de setembro de 2014, Búzios-RJ.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Introdução: Glutamato monossódico (MSG) é utilizado mundialmente como um intensificador de sabor dos alimentos. Em animais, seu uso durante o desenvolvimento pode afetar o desenvolvimento e funções neurais. Demonstramos anteriormente (Int. J. Develop. Neurosci. 33:98, 2014) que a administração repetida de MSG em ratos no período neonatal facilita a propagação do fenômeno da Depressão Alastrante Cortical (DAC) e que o exercício físico atenua esse efeito. No entanto, nada se sabe sobre efeitos agudos no cérebro adulto.
Objetivos: caracterizar possíveis alterações na propagação da DAC provocadas pelo tratamento agudo com o MSG (aplicação tópica cerebral na vida adulta), associado ao tratamento sistêmico prévio com MSG ou solução salina (veículo). Adicionalmente, analisou-se o impacto benéfico da atividade física sobre esse efeito.
Métodos: Ratos Wistar (n=36), receberam MSG (4g/kg; n=23) ou solução salina (n=13), a cada dois dias, nos primeiros 14 dias de vida pós-natal. Após o desmame, os grupos foram subdivididos em Exercitados (corrida em esteira motorizada, por 3 semanas, 5 dias/semana, durante 30 minutos; n=12 MSG e 7 salina), ou sedentários (n=11 MSG e 6 salina). Aos 120-150 dias de vida, os animais foram anestesiados (1 g/kg uretana+40 mg/kg cloralose) e submetidos ao registro da DAC em 2 pontos da superfície cortical parietal. A cada 20 minutos a DAC foi deflagrada, por aplicação de KCl a 2% por 1 min. Após uma hora de ?registro basal?, seguiram-se 3 aplicações tópicas (MSG 50mg/ml) no primeiro ponto do registro a cada 20 minutos, e um período de recuperação por 1 hora, no qual mais 3 episódios de DAC foram registrados. O mesmo procedimento foi realizado no ponto 2. Foram comparadas as velocidades da DAC antes e após a aplicação tópica de MSG.
Resultados: Ao contrário do tratamento sistêmico, a aplicação tópica do MSG reduziu reversivelmente a velocidade da DAC, tanto no grupo sedentário quanto no exercitado. No grupo MSG sedentário, as velocidades na sequên

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Low omega-3/DHA containing diets delays axonal elimination and the differentiation of cholinergic markers in the rodent visual system
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO-INGLES: Low omega-3/DHA containing diets delays axonal elimination and the differentiation of cholinergic markers in the rodent visual system

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: Society for Neurosciences Annual Meeting - 2014

AUTORES.NOME-COMPLETO-DO-AUTOR: Belmira Lara da Silveira Andrade da Costa

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Abstract:
Visual subcortical connections develop terminal field specificities through the selective elimination of misplaced axons and the maintenance of correct axonal branches, processes that underlie the use-dependent fine-tuning of topographical maps. In the present work, we studied the impact of a dietary restriction of omega-3 fatty acids on the development of eye specific segregation and topographical specificity of retinofugal pathways. We also studied the impact of low omega-3 diets on the differentiation of retinal layers and cholinergic markers in the retina. Female Lister Hooded rats and their litters were fed with either control (soy oil) or restricted (coconut oil) omega-3 diets. At various postnatal ages, rat pups received eye injections of neuronal tracers to visualize retinal axons at their brain targets. Lipid analysis indicated that the experimental diet led to a selective reduction in DHA content in the visual system. Omega-3 restriction induced an increase in the density of retinal axons in the superficial layers of the SC. This effect was observed throughout the stratum griseum superficiale (SGS), including the ventral and intermediate SGS layers at PND13, PND28 and PND42. The same pattern of expanded terminal fields was observed in the retinogeniculate pathways. The supplementation with fish oil (DHA) for two weeks was able to reverse the abnormal expansion of the retinocollicular projection. We also studied possible mechanisms involved in the loss of synaptic stabilization. Restricted omega-3 groups showed, in the visual layers of the SC decreased levels of GAP-43 phosphorylated form (pGAP-43) consistent with a reduction in synaptic stabilization. Omega-3 restriction increased the content of AMPAR subunits (GluR1 and GluR2) and decreased NMDAR (NR1, NR2A and NR2B) subunits. Omega-3 restricted groups showed a decrease in RXR?¿ content and CREB phosphorylation (pCREB) in the visual layers of the superior colliculus. Retinal differentiation was

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: A low-tryptophan diet modulates spreading depression in the rat cortex.

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: 9th World Congress, International Brain Research Organization

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Aims: The pharmacological treatment of rats with serotoninergic drugs clearly suggests an antagonistic role for the serotoninergic activity against the propagation of the excitability-related phenomenon known as cortical spreading depression (CSD). Here we investigated the possible action of a low-tryptophan diet on CSD propagation in the rat cortex.

Methods: Male Wistar rats received a 22% protein, low-tryptophan (0.05%) diet during gestation+lactation (group G+L; n=8), or during only lactation (group L; n=12), or at adulthood (group Ad; n=11). The dietary protein was from corn plus gelatin, which were very poor in tryptophan. Control groups (10 GL, 16 L and 6 Ad rats) received the same diet that was supplemented with 1% tryptophan. CSD was elicited in the frontal cortex at 20 min intervals by a 1-min application of a cotton ball (1-2 mm diameter) soaked with 2% KCl solution. We calculated the CSD velocity of propagation from the time required for a CSD wave to pass the distance between the two cortical electrodes. Data were analyzed by ANOVA, followed by a post-hoc test (Holm-Sidak). P values of less than 0.05 were considered significant.
Results: Compared with the respective controls, the tryptophan-deficient groups displayed higher (p < 0.01) CSD velocities. In the rats treated during lactation, the CSD acceleration was observed both just after weaning (recording at 30 days of life) and later in adulthood (recordings at 90 days of life). The mean (± standard deviation) CSD velocities for the low-tryptophan versus tryptophan-supplemented controls were (in mm/min): for the G+L groups, 3.85±0.27 versus 3.19±0.16; for the L groups, 3.75±0.20 versus 3.28±0.11 at 30 days of life, and 3.61±0.17 versus 3.18±0.08 at 90 days; for the Ad groups, 3.68±0.19 versus 3.21±0.11.
Conclusions: Data demonstrate that dietary tryptophan deficiency is associated with higher CSD propagation velocities. Considering that tryptophan is the precursor of serotonin synthesis, we suggest

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Effects of brain topical application of tibolone on the cortical spreading depression in castrated and non-castrated male rats.

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: 9th World Congress, International Brain Research Organization

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Aims:
Sex steroid hormones can modulate cortical excitability, with an important repercussion on brain electrophysiological properties. Tibolone (TIB), a synthetic steroid, has been proposed as a neuroendocrine- and neurotransmitter modulator, exerting neuroprotective effects in in vivo and in vitro injury models. On the other hand, experimental evidence points to a role for the castration of male rats in neuronal activity and excitability. TIB can also increase free testosterone levels. However, it is unknown if castration modulates such TIB effect in males. Here we addressed this issue by characterizing the brain ability to propagate the phenomenon designated as Cortical Spreading Depression (CSD) in castrated and non-castrated male adult rats. CSD has been used as a physiological index to analyze the effects of topical TIB on the cerebral cortex.
Methods:
Wistar male adult rats (2-3 months old) were surgically castrated (n=8). After seven days, they were subjected to a 6-7 h CSD recording session, during which TIB (10 mg/ml) was topically applied, in a sequential manner, over two circular cortical regions (3?4 mm diameter) on the intact dura-mater. This castrated group was compared with a naïve (non-castrated) control group (n=10). The CSD propagation was evaluated before and after TIB application.
Results: 
After TIB application on the recording point 1, the basal CSD velocities (3.04±0.17 mm/min and 3.33±0.16 mm/min for castrated and naïve groups, respectively), fell to 2.75±0.26 mm/min and 2.86±0.19 mm/min, respectively (P<0.001). After the TIB effect was documented, the treated region was dried with cotton and subsequent CSD episodes confirmed the return of SD velocity to the basal levels (3.40±0.36 mm/min and 3.44±0.26 mm/min). Thereafter, a second application of TIB on the recording point 2 reduced the CSD velocities in the castrated and naïve groups to 2.79±0.32 mm/min and 3.00±0.24 mm/min, respectively, and the removal of TIB was followed by returnin

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: The potentiation of ECoG after spreading depression is modulated in adult rats by anesthetic agents, and by unfavorable lactation.

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: 9th World Congress, International Brain Research Organization

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Cortical spreading depression (CSD) is characterized by reversible reduction of the evoked and spontaneous electrical activity in the cerebral cortex. Experimental evidence has suggested that CSD can modulate neural excitability and synaptic activity, with possible implications for the long-term potentiation. Systemic factors like anesthetic agents and hypoglycemia may influence CSD propagation, as well as the lactation conditions of the animal. We investigated the influence of two types of anesthetic agents (urethane + alpha-chloralose or tribromoethanol) on the possible effects of CSD in enhancing the electrocorticographic activity (ECoG) in adult male Wistar rats that were previously suckled in favorable and unfavorable conditions of lactation. Additionally, we observed whether this potentiation effect may be modulated by insulin-induced hypoglycemia. The rats were previously suckled in litters formed by 6 or 12 pups (termed L6 and L12 groups; respectively favorable and unfavorable lactation condition). In adulthood, we evaluate the increase in amplitude of electrocorticogram after the cortical tissue had been exposed to CSD in two cortical points with the support of an algorithm implemented in Matlab ? software. In the L12 condition, the rats presented significantly lower body- and brain weights than L6 control rats. Our data suggest that anesthetic agents and lactation condition modulate the potentiation induced by CSD on the amplitude of the ECoG and that insulin-induced hypoglycemia does not modify the anesthetic agents? effect. We also confirmed the regional cortical difference in potentiation of ECoG in anesthetized animals. Further studies shall deeply investigate the relevance of these findings for certain neurological diseases related to brain excitability, such as epilepsy.
Finantial support: Conselho Nacional de Desenvolvimento Científico e Tecnológico (CNPq- No. 140703/2011-0), Instituto Brasileiro de Neurociências (IBN-Net/Finep no. 4191), and Capes

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Chronic treatment of adult rats with taurine or alanine decelerates cortical spreading depression.

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: 9th World Congress, International Brain Research Organization

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Introduction: The amino acids taurine and alanine are very abundant in mammals, and experimental evidence points to a role for both amino acids in several physiological processes in the nervous system. Previous studies have demonstrated the participation of these amino acids in the fine and meticulous balance between excitatory and inhibitory mechanisms within the brain. However, the brain electrophysiological features of taurine and alanine have been poorly investigated.
Objective: We investigated in adult rats the possible action of chronic treatment with taurine or alanine on the excitability-dependent phenomenon known as cortical spreading depression (CSD).
Methods: Male Wistar rats received from postnatal day 90 to 110, per gavage, either 300 mg/kg/d taurine (T; n=9), or 300 mg/kg/d L-alanine (A; n=9), or vehicle (distilled water - W; n=8), or no treatment (naïve condition ? Nv; n=9). The volume administered per gavage was 1.0 ml/100g body weight/day. At 116-120 days, under urethane+chloralose anesthesia, we recorded CSD at two points of the cortical surface during four hours. CSD was elicited at 20 min intervals by a 1-min application of a cotton ball (1-2 mm diameter) soaked with 2% KCl solution. We measured the amplitude and duration of the CSD negative DC-shift, and calculated the CSD velocity of propagation from the time required for a CSD wave to pass the distance between the two cortical electrodes. Data were analyzed by ANOVA, followed by a post-hoc test (Holm-Sidak). P values of less than 0.05 were considered significant.
Results: Compared with the naïve- and vehicle-treated controls (CSD velocities in mm/min: 3.31±0.07 and 3.32±0.07, respectively), the groups chronically treated with taurine or alanine displayed significantly lower velocity of CSD (2.95±0.11 mm/min and 2.94±0.15 mm/min; P < 0.001). The amplitude and duration of the CSD negative DC-shift ranged respectively from 9.41±1.94 mV to 10.66±3.73 mV, and from 68.10±2.23 s to 69.76±4.03 s. N

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Serotoninergic influence on cortical spreading depression in the rat: evidence from electrical stimulation of the raphe nuclei complex.

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: 9th World Congress, International Brain Research Organization

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Aims: Evidence from rats treated with tryptophan or other serotoninergic drugs strongly suggest that exogenous serotonin slows the propagation of the excitability-related phenomenon known as cortical spreading depression (CSD). However, little is known about the functional role played on CSD by the widespread projections from serotonin-containing neurons located in the raphe nuclei. Here, we analyzed CSD changes after artificially activating the raphe nuclei by means of electrical stimulation.
Methods: The experimental procedures were previously approved by our institutional ethics committee. Under anesthesia (1 g/kg urethane+40 mg/kg chloralose, i.p.), we recorded CSD at two cortical surface points of male Wistar adult rats (n=12). CSD was elicited at 20 min intervals by a 1-min application of a cotton ball (1-2 mm diameter) soaked with 2% KCl solution. We calculated CSD velocity of propagation from the time required for a CSD wave to pass between two cortical electrodes located at a known distance. After a 1-h baseline recording, a bipolar stimulating electrode was stereotaxically inserted (AP=-7.8; ML=0.5; Depth=5.6) into the raphe nuclei complex, which was then stimulated during 20 min (1,200 square-wave pulses, 100 µA, 1 ms duration, 1 Hz). After stimulation ended, CSD recording continued for 2 hours.
Results: Compared with the baseline value (3.29±0.20 mm/min), CSD velocity decreased significantly after raphe stimulation to 2.61±0.43 mm/min (P<0.001). In a control (sham) group (n=7), in which the stimulating electrode was inserted but no current was delivered, CSD velocity both before and after electrode insertion remained unchanged (respectively, 3.18±0.42 and 3.16±0.32 mm/min; P>0.9). In all 19 animals, histological examination confirmed that the tip of the stimulating electrode was located in the lateral portion of the raphe nuclei complex ipsilateral to the CSD-recorded cortex.
Conclusion: Our electrophysiological data demonstrate that stimulation of th

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Aspartame treatment early in life modulates brain electrical activity at adulthood: a cortical spreading depression analysis in rats.

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: 9th World Congress, International Brain Research Organization

AUTORES.NOME-COMPLETO-DO-AUTOR: Paula Catirina Pereira da Silva Germano
Manoel Augisto Barbosa da Costa Mendonça

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Aspartame is a non-caloric sweetener that has been widely consumed by a growing number of human beings. Although evidence on the possible harmful effects of aspartame on neuronal function is still controversial, some data suggest association of aspartame intake with metabolic damage to the central nervous system, including changes in enzyme activities and neurotransmitters. However, little is known about the aspartame effects on brain electrophysiological activity. Here we characterized electrophysiologically the excitability-related phenomenon known as cortical spreading depression (CSD) in adult rats that were previously treated with Aspartame early-in-life.
METHODS:
From postnatal days 7 to 28, rat pups received, per gavage, either Aspartame (75 mg/kg/day, n = 10) or vehicle (distilled water; n = 10). A third group of gavage-free rats was studied as additional control (naïve group; n=10). When the animals became adults (90-120 days of age), they were anesthetized and subjected to CSD recording on two cortical points during 4 hours. CSD was elicited by 1-min application of a cotton ball (1-2 mm diameter) soaked in KCl (2% solution) at 20-min intervals, and CSD propagation velocity was calculated based on the time spent for a CSD wave to pass the interelectrode distance.
RESULTS:
KCl stimulation in one point of the frontal cortex consistently elicited CSD that propagated and was recorded at the two points of the parietal surface, both in control and in ASP-75 groups. The CSD velocities (mean ± sd in mm/min) for the naïve- and water-controls were respectively 3.33±0.02 and 3.25±0.08. Compared to the controls, ASP-75-treated rats displayed lower CSD-velocities (2.89±0.10; P<0.05).
CONCLUSION:
The main outcome of this study is that the treatment with Aspartame early in life decelerates CSD propagation in adulthood, suggesting a long lasting effect on the cortical electrical activity in the developing brain. Given the high number of people exposed to this artific

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.NOME-DA-EDITORA: Int. Soc. for Cerebral Blood Flow and Metabolism

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: NEONATAL TREATMENT WITH OVARIAN HORMONES MODULATES CORTICAL SPREADING DEPRESSION IN ADULT FEMALE RATS PREVIOUSLY SUCKLED IN NORMAL SIZE- AND LARGE SIZE LITTERS
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO-INGLES: NEONATAL TREATMENT WITH OVARIAN HORMONES MODULATES CORTICAL SPREADING DEPRESSION IN ADULT FEMALE RATS PREVIOUSLY SUCKLED IN NORMAL SIZE- AND LARGE SIZE LITTERS

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: 2nd Congress of the Federation of Latin-American and Caribbean Societies for Neuroscience (FALAN)

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Aims
Ovarian hormones (OH) and early malnutrition may
affect the brain excitability. We demonstrated that early
ovariectomy decelerated the Cortical Spreading Depression
(CSD) (Accioly et al, Int. J. Dev. Neurosci. 2012). Here we
characterized the effect of treatment with OH on CSD in
female rats previously suckled in normal size- or large size
litters as a way of inducing malnutrition.
Methods
Wistar female rats were suckled in litters with 6-9 and
12-15 pups (L9 and L15 groups, respectively). The L15
condition was previously shown to provoke moderate
malnutrition. From postnatal days (P) 7 to 21, pups received
50 μg/kg β-estradiol (15 L9 rats and 10 L15 rats), or 50 μg/
kg progesterone (10 L9 rats and 12 L15 rats), or olive oil
(vehicle, V; 15 L9 rats and 9 L15 rats), or no treatment (naïve,
Nv; without any treatment; 8 L9 rats and 12 L15 rats). At P90-
120 we analyzed CSD parameters. Approved by the ethics
committee/UFPE Process nº 23076.010208/2012-09
Results
L15 rats presented with higher CSD velocities and
amplitudes, and shorter duration (p < 0.05) in comparison
with the L9 animals. Both OH increased CSD velocity and
amplitude, and decreased CSD duration, in comparison
with the naive and olive oil-treated controls (p < 0.5).
Conclusions
Systemic treatment with OH early in life is associated with
CSD positive modulation in the adult brain. OH might act
on synaptic transmission. Furthermore, early nutritional
deficiency (L15 condition) modulated the effect of OH on
CSD.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Influence of early and late swimming exercise on behavioral parameters in well-nourished and early-malnourished rats
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO-INGLES: Influence of early and late swimming exercise on behavioral parameters in well-nourished and early-malnourished rats

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: IUPS 38 World Congress

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Nutritional deficiency and swimming exercise in early life are factors that can affect the behavioral organization of the brain during development. In this study we investigate, in well-nourished and early-malnourished rats, the possible effects of swimming exercise, in early life and in adulthood, on behavioral parameters suggestive of anxiety. Male Wistar rats were suckled in normal-size or large-size litters (with 6 or 12 pups, respectively; L6 and L12 groups). Early and late swimming was performed between postnatal days (P) 8-23 and 60-75, respectively. Control animals remained sedentary. The behavioral tests (open field ? OF and object recognition ? OR) were conducted between P77-P80. For the OF the following parameters were considered: total distance traveled, number of entries in the central zone, and percent time spent in central zone. For the OR, all objects had similar textures, colors and sizes, differing only in shapes. The criteria for exploration were based on active exploration, in which the rats must touch the object with at least their nose. Data analysis was performed by ANYmaze software (version 4.99m). Animals that swam early in life, independent of nutritional factor (L6 or L12) exhibited a greater number of entries in the center and a higher percentage of time in the center (p<0.05). In animals that swam late, this effect was observed in the L6 group only. The OR-test showed that the animals in the L6 early swimming group had better memory compared to sedentary group (p<0.05) and all other groups showed reduced performance. The data suggest that swimming exercise had an anxiolytic effect on the two nutritional conditions, but only improved the memory of nourished animals.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: NEONATAL TREATMENT WITH MONOSODIUM GLUTAMATE ACCELERATES CORTICAL SPREADING DEPRESSION IN ADULT, PREVIOUSLY CASTRATED AND NON-CASTRATED FEMALE RATS
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO-INGLES: NEONATAL TREATMENT WITH MONOSODIUM GLUTAMATE ACCELERATES CORTICAL SPREADING DEPRESSION IN ADULT, PREVIOUSLY CASTRATED AND NON-CASTRATED FEMALE RATS

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: IUPS 38th world congress

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Aims
Monosodium glutamate (MSG), a food additive worldwide used as a flavor enhancer, can induce neurotoxicity, with repercussion on brain excitability. The influence of MSG is generally more pronounced in males than in females. It is speculated that such a difference in female response to MSG occurs because of the neuroprotective action of ovarian hormones. Here we characterized the effect of treatment with MSG on the excitability-dependent phenomenon designated as Cortical Spreading Depression (CSD) in female adult rats that had been previously castrated and non-castrated.

Methods
Newborn Wistar female rats (n = 39) constituted four experimental groups: 1), ovariectomized on P7 and treated with 4 mg/g MSG (n= 11); 2) ovariectomized and treated with vehicle (saline; n = 10); 3) sham-surgery plus 4 mg/g MSG (n = 8), and 4) sham-surgery plus vehicle (n = 10). At P90-120 we recorded CSD over 4h and analyzed the velocity of propagation. Approved by the ethics committee/UFPE Process nº 23076.048735/2014-40.

Results

MSG-treated groups showed significantly higher mean velocities (4.16 ± 0.26 mm/min) than controls (3.13 ± 0.33 mm/min). Ovariectomy early in life attenuated the facilitatory effect of MSG on CSD (p < 0.05; Figure 1).
 
Conclusions
Systemic treatment with MSG and OVX early in life is associated with CSD modulation in the adult brain. It is suggested that such effects are related to the long-term action of ovarian hormones and MSG on synaptic transmission.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: TOPICAL CEREBRAL APPLICATION OF OVARIAN HORMONES MODULATES CORTICAL SPREADING DEPRESSION IN ADULT FEMALE RATS PREVIOUSLY SUCKLED UNDER DIFFERENT LITTER SIZES
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO-INGLES: TOPICAL CEREBRAL APPLICATION OF OVARIAN HORMONES MODULATES CORTICAL SPREADING DEPRESSION IN ADULT FEMALE RATS PREVIOUSLY SUCKLED UNDER DIFFERENT LITTER SIZES

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: IUPS 38 World Congress

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Aims:
Ovarian hormones (OH) influence brain excitability. In laboratory animals, the OH can be applied topically to the brain in order to study their excitability effects. Here we used such technique to study the actions of OH on cortical spreading depression (CSD).

Methods: 
Wistar female rats were suckled in litters with 6-9 pups (L9; control) or 12-15 pups (L15; nutritionally deficient). At 90-120 days of age, they underwent CSD recording, during which three distinct solutions of β-estradiol (5 mg/ml, 10 mg/ml and 20 mg/ml) and progesterone (66 mg/ml, 132 mg/ml and 264 mg/ml) were topically applied to the cortical surface. CSD parameters (propagation velocity, amplitude and duration of the negative CSD DC-shift) were evaluated before and after hormone application. 

Results:
L15 rats presented with higher CSD velocity and amplitude, and shorter duration (p < 0.05), in comparison with the L9 animals. Topic application of both ovarian hormones produced reversible and dose-dependent CSD acceleration (p < 0.05).

Conclusions:
Topical cortical application of OH is an effective technique to reversibly demonstrate the OH?s effects on CSD, avoiding metabolic and indirect influences that can be present in the systemic application paradigm. Modulation of the OH action by early nutritional deficiency could be evidenced. Our data complement the findings using systemic application, and might help understanding the action of OH on brain excitability.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: NEONATAL TREATMENT WITH OVARIAN HORMONES MODULATES RECOGNITION MEMORY IN ADULT FEMALE RATS PREVIOUSLY SUCKLED UNDER DIFFERENT LITTER SIZES
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO-INGLES: NEONATAL TREATMENT WITH OVARIAN HORMONES MODULATES RECOGNITION MEMORY IN ADULT FEMALE RATS PREVIOUSLY SUCKLED UNDER DIFFERENT LITTER SIZES

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: IUPS 38 World Congress

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Aims
Ovarian hormones (OH) and early malnutrition may affect the developing brain, with repercussion on behavioral processes. In this study we investigated in female adult rats, previously suckled in litter with different sizes, the effect of treatment in early life with OH on object recognition memory.

Methods	
Female Wistar rats (n = 91) were suckled in litters with 6-9 and 12-15 pups (L9 and L15 groups; n = 48 and 43, respectively). The L15 condition has been previously shown to provoke moderate malnutrition (Francisco and Guedes, Aminoacids 47:2437-2445, 2015). From postnatal days (P) 7 to 21, animals received 50 µg/kg of β-estradiol (n = 15 L9 rats and 10 L15 rats) or progesterone (n = 10 L9 rats and 12 L15 rats). They were compared to an olive oil-treated group (vehicle; 15 L9 rats and 9 L15 rats) and a naïve group (Nv; without any treatment; 8 L9 rats and 12 L15 rats). From P80 to P84, we tested behavioral reactions (recognition memory tasks): A) test for recognition of a novel spatial placement of a familiar object and B) test for the shape-based recognition of a novel object. Approved by the ethics committee/UFPE Process nº 23076.010208/2012-09. 

Results 
In the test for recognition of a novel spatial placement of a familiar object (Figure 1-A), L15 hormone-treated groups performed worse (shorter time exploring the object in a novel position) than the corresponding L9 hormone-treated groups (p < 0.05). In the test for the shape-based recognition of a novel object, L9 hormone-treated groups performed better (longer time exploring the novel object) than the L9 controls, and also than the corresponding L15 hormone-treated groups (p < 0.05; Figure 1-B).

Conclusions
We concluded that treatment over the course of the development with OH in association with unfavorable lactation (L15) impaired recognition memory in the adult brain. OH treatment and L15 lactation condition seem to interact regarding OH action on memory.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Administration of Testosterone in prepubertal rats impairs memory but not anxiety in adulthood
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO-INGLES: Administration of Testosterone in prepubertal rats impairs memory but not anxiety in adulthood

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: XXXII Reunião Anual da FESBE - Federação das Sociedades de Biologia Experimental

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
INTRODUTION
Testosterone plays a substantial role in a number of physiological processes that are required for brain development and functioning, including emotion, cognition, anxiety and memory. Here we characterized behavioral responses in adult rats that were previously treated (P22 ? P28) with a supraphysiological dose of testosterone.

AIMS
The objective of the present study was to evaluate the effect of supraphysiological dose of testosterone on memory and anxious behavior in rats.

METHODS:
From postnatal days 22 to 28, Wistar rats received either testosterone propionate (10 mg/kg; n=10) or vehicle (olive oil; n=11), via i.p once a day. Behavioral tests (elevated plus-maze [EPM], open field [OF] and object recognition [OR]) occurred at P80-P89.
(Approval protocol of Ethics Committee no 23076.017033/2013-33) 

RESULTS:
In the EPM test, the testosterone group entered more in the open arms (12 ± 3.4 entries), in comparison with the oil-treated (8.2 ± 4.0 entries) and naive controls (5.4 ± 3.6 entries) (p < 0.05). Regarding the OF test, no intergroup difference was observed. In the OR tests, the testosterone-treated group spent less time exploring the object in the novel spatial position (34.2 ± 2,9% of time), in comparison with the vehicle and naïve controls (respectively 66.9 ± 7.7% and 61.1 ± 11.0%; p < 0.05), as well as in the task for recognition of a novel shape of an object (57.3 ± 8.1% versus 80.3 ± 14.7% and 70.7 ± 12.8% for vehicle and naïve controls; p < 0.05).
CONCLUSION:
Overall, the results suggest that testosterone early in life can positively modulate anxiety and negatively influence spatial memory. The search for the molecular mechanisms underlying such testosterone effects shall be further investigated.
FINANCIAL SUPPORT: Capes, CNPq, Facepe, Propesq/UFPE.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Quantitative Analysis of Early Genes Expression after Spreading Depression in the Rat Somatosensory Cortex: Stereological Analysis of EGR1 immunolabeling
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO-INGLES: Quantitative Analysis of Early Genes Expression after Spreading Depression in the Rat Somatosensory Cortex: Stereological Analysis of EGR1 immunolabeling

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: 11 Forum of Neurosciences of the Federation of the European Neuroscience Societies

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Cortical spreading depression (CSD) has been described as an episode of electrical silence that propagates in the grey matter as a wave of cortical depolarization, following intense neuronal activity. Although it has been previously recognized that CSD acutely increases early gene expression in the brain, so far there is no detailed quantitative analysis using unbiased stereological methods to investigate potential correlations between the number of CSD episodes and Erg1 expression in infragranular cortical layers. In the present report, we recorded CSD waves at two sites aligned in anteroposterior direction and parallel to midline. Topical application of 2% KCl for 1 min at the cortical surface, induced CSD waves which were recorded using a pair of Ag?AgCl, agar-Ringer electrodes placed more posteriorly. Electrophysiological recordings were made for two hours and then were then perfuse-fixed. A vibratome-cut anatomical series from both right (control) and left (CSD) hemispheres were generated and an optical fractionator was used to count Erg1 positive cells in two distinct experimental groups: those with high and those with low numbers of CSD episodes. The CSD hemispheres of both groups showed higher positively stained cell densities than hemispheres of their respective controls (right hemispheres). Individuals with higher number episodes showed significant higher number of Erg1 positive cells than those with lower number episodes. Taken together results suggest strong correlation between number episodes and Erg1 expression in the infragranular layers 2 hours after the 1st CSD episode.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Stereological analysis of spreading depression-induced Egr-1 immunolabeled cells, in the rat somatosensory cortex

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: International Conference on Spreading Depolarization.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: OPTIMIZATION OF VAGUS NERVE STIMULATION EFFICACY ON CORTICAL SPREADING DEPRESSION.
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO-INGLES: OPTIMIZATION OF VAGUS NERVE STIMULATION EFFICACY ON CORTICAL SPREADING DEPRESSION.

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: 12th European Headache Federation Congress

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Introduction: Vagus nerve stimulation (VNS) acutely suppresses cortical
spreading depression (CSD) susceptibility, which is a clinically-relevant
animal model to screen for migraine therapies. We aimed to optimize
VNS efficacy on CSD using various stimulation protocols.
Methods: VNS (1ms pulse of 5kHz sine waves at 25 Hz) was delivered
non-invasively (nVNS) using cutaneous bipolar disc electrodes. Stimulus
trains were generated using a customized stimulator modified from the
current gammaCore nVNS device (electroCore LLC, Basking Ridge, NJ).
Systemic physiology was monitored during the stimulation. CSD susceptibility
was evaluated 40 min after the last stimulation. Experiment 1
determined the optimal nVNS protocol among sham (N=8), 1x2-min
(N=5), 2x2-min 5 min apart (N=8), 3x2-min 5 min apart (N=9), and 1x6-
min (N=8) stimulation protocols. Experiment 2 evaluated chronic daily
nVNS for 4 weeks using the most efficient protocol from Experiment 1.
Daily femoral nerve stimulation (nFNS) was used as control.
Results: Among the studied protocols 2x2-min 5 min apart was the
most efficient in suppress CSD susceptibility. This protocol increased
electrical threshold by 68% and decreased in 22% KCl- induced CSD
frequency. Other protocols yielded weaker efficacy (Fig. 1). Chronic
nVNS was responsible for 68% increase in electrical CSD threshold and
35% decrease in KCl-induced CSD frequency when compared to nFNS.
Discussion: Our results suggest that chronic nVNS may be more effective
than the acute stimulation in suppressing CSD.
Ethics Approval
Experiments were carried out in accordance with the Guide for Care
and Use of Laboratory Animals (NIH Publication No. 85-23, 1996), and
approved by the institutional review board.
INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES:
Introduction: Vagus nerve stimulation (VNS) acutely suppresses cortical
spreading depression (CSD) susceptibility, which is a clinically-relevant
animal model to screen for migraine therapies. We aimed to optimize
VNS efficacy on CSD using various stimulation protocols.
Methods: VNS (1ms pulse of 5kHz sine waves at 25 Hz) was delivered
non-invasively (nVNS) using cutaneous bipolar disc electrodes. Stimulus
trains were generated using a customized stimulator modified from the
current gammaCore nVNS device (electroCore LLC, Basking Ridge, NJ).
Systemic physiology was monitored during the stimulation. CSD susceptibility
was evaluated 40 min after the last stimulation. Experiment 1
determined the optimal nVNS protocol among sham (N=8), 1x2-min
(N=5), 2x2-min 5 min apart (N=8), 3x2-min 5 min apart (N=9), and 1x6-
min (N=8) stimulation protocols. Experiment 2 evaluated chronic daily
nVNS for 4 weeks using the most efficient protocol from Experiment 1.
Daily femoral nerve stimulation (nFNS) was used as control.
Results: Among the studied protocols 2x2-min 5 min apart was the
most efficient in suppress CSD susceptibility. This protocol increased
electrical threshold by 68% and decreased in 22% KCl- induced CSD
frequency. Other protocols yielded weaker efficacy (Fig. 1). Chronic
nVNS was responsible for 68% increase in electrical CSD threshold and
35% decrease in KCl-induced CSD frequency when compared to nFNS.
Discussion: Our results suggest that chronic nVNS may be more effective
than the acute stimulation in suppressing CSD.
Ethics Approval
Experiments were carried out in accordance with the Guide for Care
and Use of Laboratory Animals (NIH Publication No. 85-23, 1996), and
approved by the institutional review board.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Vagus Nerve Stimulation and Cortical Spreading Depression.

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: 20th meeting presented by: Co-Operative Studies on Brain Injury Depolarizations

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Introduction: Vagus nerve stimulation (VNS) acutely suppresses cortical spreading
depression (CSD) susceptibility (Chen et al, 2016). Mechanisms of CSD
suppression are unknown.
Methods: VNS (1ms pulse of 5kHz sine waves at 25 Hz) was delivered either
non-invasively (nVNS) using cutaneous bipolar disc electrodes, or invasively
(iVNS) using implanted bipolar hook electrodes. Stimulus trains were generated
delivered using a customized stimulator modified from the current gammaCore
nVNS device (electroCore LLC, Basking Ridge, NJ). Systemic physiology was
monitored during the stimulation. CSD susceptibility was evaluated 40 min after
the stimulation last. Experiment 1 determined the optimal nVNS protocol among
1x2-min, 2x2-min 5 min apart, 3x2-min 5 min apart, and 1x6-min. In Experiment
2 examined the effect of proximal or distal vagotomy on iVNS efficacy to
suppress CSD. Experiment 3 tested serotonergic (5-HT) and Norepinephrinergic
(NE) involvement in VNS effect by using the drugs PCPA (100mg/kg) and DSP-4
(150mg/kg) 3 and 14 days prior to nVNS, respectively.
Results: Among the studied protocols two 2-min stimulation 5 min apart was
the most efficient. iVNS was responsible for 57.4% increase in electrical CSD
threshold and 22% decrease in KCl-induced CSD frequency when an intact
vagus nerve was stimulated. Distal vagotomy did alter the efficacy (55.4% higher
threshold and 19% lower frequency). Proximal vagotomy completely abolished
iVNS effect on CSD susceptibility. Both lesions (proximal and distal) increased
CSD frequency by 10% by themselves. nVNS decreased CSD frequency by
25% and this effect was partially blocked by DSP-4 and PCPA. Two 2-min nVNS
provided the optimal efficacy.
Discussion: Our results suggest that central 5-HT and NE pathways mediate
VNS suppression of CSD.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Effect of melatonin administration during brain development on behavioral and electrophysiological features in young rats
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO-INGLES: Effect of melatonin administration during brain development on behavioral and electrophysiological features in young rats

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: Congresso da Federação Latino-Americana de Neurociências (FALAN)

AUTORES.NOME-COMPLETO-DO-AUTOR: Arthur Gabriel Alves Furtado de Carvalho Noya

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
ABSTRACT
INTRODUCTION: Melatonin (MLT) is a hormone that has beneficial effects in neurological diseases. MLT can interact with other physiological systems to control behaviors such as anxiety and depression. Cortical spreading depression (CSD) is a fully reversible, depolarizing phenomenon that is involved in several neurological diseases, such as migraine, epilepsy, subarachnoid hemorrhage and traumatic brain injury. The study by Le Grand et al. (2006) has shown that, in addition to its role in normal physiological condition, MLT is also effective in attenuating CSD-induced hyperemia.
OBJECTIVES: The present study aimed to investigate, in the developing rat brain, the effect of early-in-life administration of two different doses of MLT on behavioral (anxiety and memory) and electrophysiological parameters (CSD analysis), as will be described below. We hypothesize that MLT differentially affects both the behavioral and CSD parameters, as a function of the MLT dose.
METHODS: Wistar rats received, from the 7th to the 27th postnatal day (PND), on alternate days, vehicle solution, or 10 mg/kg or 40 mg/kg of MLT (MLT-10 and MLT-40 groups), or no treatment (intact group). From PND30 to PND34, the animals were tested in the open field apparatus (OF), first for anxiety (PND30) and then for object recognition memory tasks: spatial position recognition - PR (PND31) and shape recognition ? SR (PND32). On PND34, they were tested in the elevated plus maze (EPM). From PND36 to 42, the CSD phenomenon was recorded, and its propagation velocity was quantified.
RESULTS: Treatment with MLT did not change the animals' body weight neither blood glucose levels. However, the MLT-10 treatment was associated with behaviors that suggest less anxiety (more entries and more time spent in the anxiogenic areas of the aparatus) and an improved object recognition memory (more time exploring the novel aspects of the object recognition task).. MLT-10 and MLT-40 treatments respectively decelerat

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Propagation Of Cortical Spreading Depression In Malnourished Rats: Facilitatory Effect Of Dietary Protein Deficiency.

DETALHAMENTO-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-PERIODICO-OU-REVISTA: Brazilian Journal of Medical and Biological Research

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Abstract:
Adult rats, submitted from gestation to the basic regional diet (BRD) of some human populations in the northeastern region of Brazil, presented higher velocities of propagation of cortical spreading depression (SD) than well-nourished animals. This effect was also seen in rats receiving BRD during the gestation and suckling periods alone but not when this diet was administered only during adult life, suggesting that the alterations produced by BRD occur early in life. The supplementation of BRD with lipids, vitamins and minerals (but not protein) did not prevent the appearance of this facilitatory effect in the gestation + suckling group, suggesting an important effect of protein deficiency in the BRD on cortical SD.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Sciatic Nerve Conduction Velocity Of Malnourished Rats Fed The Humanbasic Regional Diet Of The Northeast Of Brazil.

DETALHAMENTO-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-PERIODICO-OU-REVISTA: Brazilian Journal of Medical and Biological Research

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: 1. Rats were fed the "basic regional diet" (BRD) utilized by some human populations in northeastern Brazil, which contains only 7.8% protein (mainly from beans), to produce a form of malnutrition. The effects of chronic malnutrition on nerve impulse conduction velocity was studied in the sciatic nerve of young (121-143 days) and old (420-540 days) rats. 2. BRD rats presented a 50% reduction in sciatic nerve conduction velocity compared to controls fed a diet containing 22% casein. 3. Rats chronically fed a commercially available diet (CD group) containing an intermediate level of protein (14%) presented conduction velocities intermediate between values obtained from control and BRD rats (62% to 76% of the control values). 4. The conduction velocities of animals belonging to the same nutritional group were independent of sex, body weight or age. 5. Nutritional restriction imposed only in adult life by increasing the number of rats per cage in the casein group did not have any effect on the conduction velocity of nerve impulses. 6. The severity of the effects observed in the malnourished rats may be related to the quantity and quality of protein in the diet. In this respect, the present data agree with those reported in the literature on human and animal experiments. 7. The present results justify the use of the foods ingested by malnourished human populations for the development of experimental animal models of malnutrition.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: On Some Conditions That Influence Cortical Spreading Depression

DETALHAMENTO-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-PERIODICO-OU-REVISTA: Anais da Academia Brasileira de Ciências

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Neuropharmacological Properties Of Eletrophysiologically Identified, Visually Responsive Neurones Of The Posterior Lateral Suprasylvian Area. A Microiontophoretic Study.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Extracellular recordings have been made from 118 electrophysiologically identified neurones lying in the posterior lateral suprasylvian area (PLLS and PLMS) of cats anaesthetized with Nembutal. Eighty-one cells were activated synaptically by the electrical stimulation of cortical and subcortical sites known to be the sources of monosynaptic projections to the lateral suprasylvian area; latencies to such activations have been measured. The locations and sizes of the receptive fields of 55 neurones were determined. The direction sensitivity and ocularity of these cells also were examined. The effects of various pharmacological agonists and antagonists have been observed on visual responsiveness and synaptic excitability. The excitatory effects of subcortical (dorsal lateral geniculate nucleus and pulvinar nuclear complex) electrical stimulation on the activity of suprasylvian neurones were reduced substantially by the iontophoretic administration of atropine. Antagonists of the receptors for the excitatory amino acids reduced the effectiveness, on the single cell evoked activity, of stimulation of the ipsilateral 17/18 border region and contralateral homotopic lateral suprasylvian area. Both classes of antagonist reduced the magnitude of neuronal responses to photic stimulation, and these response attenuations were additive when the antagonists were ejected concurrently. All of the pharmacological effects were reversible and reproducible. These data lend support to the proposition that acetylcholine and an excitatory amino acid are mediators of synaptic transmission of cortical visual processes in the lateral suprasylvian area.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Functional Role Of Association Fibres For A Visual Association Area: The Posterior Suprasylvian Sulcus Of The Cat.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: This paper reports on experiments in which the effect of disconnection of association fibres from Area 17/18 to the posterior suprasylvian cortex (PSSC) was investigated. In the control experiments, all neurons had large receptive fields in the central 5-10 degrees of the visual field without detailed retinotopy. In the medial bank of PSSC, receptive fields were located in the contralateral visual field, while receptive fields of neurons in the lateral bank were located ipsilaterally. Neurons in PSSC could be excited by electrical stimulation of the ipsilateral Area 17/18 boundary, of the medial pulvinar (N. lat. post., pars. lat.) and the lateral geniculate body. About 2/3 of all neurons could be excited from all these regions, although with varying latencies. After acute and chronic subpial undercutting of the representation of the central 5-10 degrees of the ipsilateral area 17/18, visual response properties including direction sensitivity, receptive field size and ocularity of PSSC-neurons in the medio-posterior bank did not change significantly. After ablation of the whole contralateral visual cortex (including PSSC and a wide region of the contralateral Clare-Bishop area) the input from the ipsilateral eye was considerably diminished, but other response properties did not change significantly. These essentially negative findings are discussed in relation to different findings of other authors, and it is argued that the subpial undercutting of only the central visual field representation may have prevented damage to the ipsilateral suprasylvian cortex and its afferents, which is difficult to avoid if the whole area 17 is ablated by suction. It is proposed, that association fibres may only "unspecifically" excite neurons in related association areas rather than impose onto them specific response features. These latter are derived, also in association areas, essentially from their thalamic afferents and their intracortical interaction.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Opioid Mechanisms Involved In The Slow Potential Change And Neuronal Refractoriness During Cortical Spreading Depression.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Abstract:
The slow potential change (spc) accompanying spreading depression (SD) was studied in rats and in a seizure-sensitive strain of Mongolian gerbil under three different experimental paradigms, each involving the use of naloxone. Gerbils undergoing electroconvulsive shock treatment displayed SD during the post-ictal phase, which was blocked by the intraperitoneal (i.p.) administration of naloxone (20-50 mg kg-1). Topical application of naloxone to the exposed cortex of the anaesthetized gerbil and rat blocked the spc of SD evoked by KCl. Microiontophoretic ejection of naloxone during extracellular recordings reversed cell refractoriness following the spc, demonstrated by the observation of a maintained sensitivity to iontophoretic pulses of glutamate. The results suggest a possible involvement of naloxone-sensitive processes in the mechanism responsible for cortical SD.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Lasting Effects Of Dehydration And Postweaning Undernourishment On Spreading Depression In Rats.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Abstract
Acute dehydration (D) early in life made adult rats less susceptible to cortical spreading depression (SD) than control (C) rats. Post weaning undernourished (U) rats tended to be more susceptible than controls. The association of D and U (DU group) made rats more susceptible to SD than U-rats. It is suggested that this association gives rise to a more complex pathological state than that which would result from the summation of the effects of its components.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Synaptic Transmission In Suprasylvian Visual Cortex Is Reduced By Excitatory Amino Acid Antagonists.

DETALHAMENTO-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-PERIODICO-OU-REVISTA: Canadian Journal of Physiology and Pharmacology

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: The activities of cortical neurones lying in the Clare-Bishop area of the suprasylvian visual region in anaesthetized cats were monitored during the application of cholinergic and amino acid agonists and antagonists, as well as during sequences of light and electrical stimulation. Of those Clare-Bishop cells which could be activated at short latencies by electrical stimuli applied to the contralateral, homologous cortical zone, D-alpha-aminoadipate and 2-amino-5-phosphonovalerate antagonized neuronal responses elicited by electrically evoked synaptic activation and by the presentation of light stimuli. Acetylcholine as well as the excitatory amino acids increased the firing of many of these neurones; however only the amino acid antagonists blocked the commissurally evoked excitations although both types of antagonist reduced the magnitudes of the visually evoked responses. It therefore appears as though the same synaptic transmitter is utilized by cortical commissural afferents as is employed by the cortical ipsilateral projection to the Clare-Bishop area, and furthermore this transmitter is likely to be an excitatory amino acid.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Selective Synaptic Antagonism By Atropine And Alpha-Aminoadipate Of Pulvinar And Cortical Afferents To The Suprasylvian Visual Area(Clare Bishop Area)

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: The synaptic excitations of cells of the Clare-Bishop cortical region produced by electrical stimulation of the pulvinar and ipsilateral cortex, have been shown to be differentially antagonized by iontophoretically applied antagonists. Atropine attenuated the responses evoked by pulvinar stimulation without having an appreciable effect against either iontophoretically applied aspartate or cortically evoked responses. alpha-Aminoadipate antagonized aspartate elicited excitations and those obtained with cortical stimulation while leaving unaffected acetylcholine and pulvinar evoked responses. The results are supportive of the view that acetylcholine and aspartate, or a similar excitatory amino acid, act as synaptic transmitters of some afferents from the pulvinar and ipsilateral cerebral cortex, respectively.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Influence Of Ionic Disturbances Produced By Gastric Washing On Cortical Spreading Depression.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Abstract:
The ionic composition of the internal environment was altered in rabbits by means of gastric washing, combined with intramuscular administration of 3-Beta-aminoethylpyrazole. The effects of this treatment on cortical spreading depression (SD) were studied. Cl- and Na+ concentrations decreased significantly in serum and in cerebrospinal fluid after the treatment. This made the animals much more susceptible to SD, as established by the high incidence of "spontaneous" SD, increased SD velocity of propagation and facilitated its interhemispheric transfer. An intensification of the epileptiform activity associated with SD was also observed. Intravenous replacement of NaCl abolished the above effects of SD. When the intravenous replacement was done with Na-Isethionate, those effects were enhanced. It is concluded that chloride deficiency was the main factor responsible for the observed facilitating effects.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Learned And Emotional Behavior In Chronically Malnourished Rats.

DETALHAMENTO-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-PERIODICO-OU-REVISTA: Acta Phisiologica, Pharmacologica et Therapeutica Lationoamericana

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Weanling male and female Wistar rats, whose mothers received low protein diet (6.8%) during pregnancy and lactation, were fed on the same diet of their mothers and trained in an active avoidance situation at the ages of 60, 90 or 120 days. Control animals fed on a 20% protein diet of the same age groups were submitted to similar training. The consolidation and performance of the conditioned avoidance response and other behavioral reactions were studied. The malnourished animals showed delay of consolidation and lower frequency of conditioned avoidance responses, escape responses and holdings as well as higher frequency of anticipatory reactions, vocalization, riddance attempts and touching of surroundings. The results show that chronic malnutrition impairs the active avoidance response. They also show that chronic malnutrition affects the emotional behavior more markedly than early malnutrition. Chronic malnutrition also enhances the exploratory activity, in contrast to early malnutrition, and this is attributed to an alimentary drive-dependent mechanism.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Apromorphine Does Not Mimic The Effects Of Rem-Sleep Deprivation On Cortical Spreading Depression

DETALHAMENTO-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-PERIODICO-OU-REVISTA: Brazilian Journal of Medical and Biological Research

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: The propagation of cortical spreading depression (SD) and the incidence of "spontaneous" SD were enhanced in rats after rapid-eye-movement sleep deprivation (REMD) as compared to control animals. Pseudo-deprived rats were similar to controls, suggesting that the facilitatory effect on SD is due to REMD rather than to the stress accompanying deprivation.
